data.title: A Look Back: Ward Kimball and Perris

data.text:
Travelers using the Perris Multimodal Transit Center, dedicated

in January 2010, will notice Disney cartoon characters in the

murals decorating the combination bus-train and park-and-ride

station, which will serve as a Metrolink station in the future.

Disney art might be expected in, say, Anaheim, but the

connection between Perris and Disney is less obvious. It’s due to

Ward Kimball, a longtime Disney animator, and his love of

trains.

Kimball worked on “Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,” “Fantasia,”

“Dumbo” and other films and created the Jiminy Cricket character

for “Pinocchio.” He worked for Walt Disney Studios for some 40

years, starting in 1934, and won an Academy Award in 1969 for “It’s

Tough to Be a Bird.”

Kimball, born in 1914, “was nuts about trains,” said Joe Vargo,

public information officer for the city of Perris.

In the 1930s and ’40s, Kimball built a narrow-gauge model

railroad – full-size, to ride it on a 500-foot track – on his

family’s homestead in San Gabriel.

He called it the Grizzly Flats Railroad. Much of the rolling

stock came from railroads dismantling cars and equipment; Kimball

restored them. Grizzly Flats began with Coach 5, an 1881 car built

for the Carson & Colorado Railroad. Kimball bought it in 1938

for $50; it was the Southern Pacific Railroad’s last remaining

passenger car, according to the Orange Empire Railway Museum, in

Perris.

Grizzly Flats grew to include, among other things, an 1881

locomotive called “Emma Nevada,” from the Nevada Central Railway;

and Chloe, a 1917 sugar plantation locomotive the Kimballs named

for their daughter.

Being a train buff, Kimball liked to visit OERM – so much so

that in 1990, the Kimballs donated much of the Grizzly Flats

Railroad to the museum, plus money to install a four-track engine

house to display it. Kimball died in 2002. His widow, Betty, passed

away last year, said John Smatlak, OERM’s vice president of

collections. But today visitors to OERM can still see Kimball’s

beloved collection in a big red barn at OERM.

When the city of Perris was planning the transit center, civic

leaders, knowing of Kimball’s generosity to the railroad museum,

wanted to honor him by incorporating some of his drawings into the

station’s décor.

Former City Councilman John Motte, the Riverside Transit Agency

and Kimball’s son, John, asked Disney officials for permission, and

got it. That’s quite an accomplishment, because “the Walt Disney

Co. is extremely protective of its brand and legacy, and often

denies use of its images on schools, walls and other public

venues,” the city’s website explains. The transit center was also

dedicated to Kimball.

So Jiminy Crickett, the Mad Hatter and Tweedledum and Tweedledee

grace the bus shelters in Perris’ transit hub. Motte says on the

city’s website that he hopes someday people can board a train in

Perris and ride to Disneyland.

OERM is at 2201 South A Street in Perris. For more information,

call 951-943-3020 or see www.oerm.org. The Perris multimodal

station is on South C Street between West Fourth and West San

Jacinto Avenue.
